content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my earnings over the 75 rounds. Since the game is symmetric, it makes sense to assume that my anonymous partner is also rational and will follow a similar strategy.

In each round, if we both choose R, we get 45$, which is good for both of us. However, if we both choose B in a round, we only earn 20$. Therefore, it seems advantageous to pick R when possible.

However, if the partner always picks R and I pick B, they get 40$ and I get 0$, which means over the course of 75 rounds, I would lose 300$ (75 rounds * 4$). On the other hand, if we switch roles and they always pick B when I pick R, then they lose 300$ over the same number of rounds. This suggests that it might be better to sometimes choose B to avoid a situation where my partner consistently gains an advantage.

To balance out the long-term gain while ensuring fairness in the short term, I would choose a mixed strategy that includes both R and B. This way, I can't predictably lose too much in the long run, while also ensuring that my partner doesn't consistently earn more than me in the early rounds.

So, as a human player, I would choose a strategy that includes both R and B, but without revealing the exact proportion to my anonymous partner. I would append my choice with a curly bracket, for example: {R} or {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In this particular round, I chose B and my opponent also chose B, so we both earned 20$. Since our choices were identical in the previous round, it doesn't provide any information about how likely either of us is to change our strategy in the future.

As a human player, I would still lean towards a mixed strategy that includes both R and B, but I might adjust my exact proportion based on the observed payoffs from the first round. In this case, since we both chose B and earned 20$, it suggests that sticking with the current strategy (B) may not be the worst decision in the long run. However, I would still keep an open mind and consider changing my strategy if I see a pattern or advantage in doing so.

So, for the next round, as a human player, I would choose {R} to introduce some variation into my strategy and to maintain the possibility of taking advantage of any potential inconsistencies in my opponent's strategy.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this particular round, I chose B and my opponent chose R, so I earned 40$ while they got nothing. This indicates that my current strategy (choosing B) might have been beneficial in this case, as it allowed me to earn a higher payoff compared to the previous round where we both earned 20$.

However, it's important to remember that this is only one data point and it doesn't necessarily predict how my opponent will behave in future rounds. As a human player, I would still be cautious and consider using a mixed strategy that includes both R and B to maintain flexibility and keep my opponent guessing.

So, for the next round, as a human player, I would choose {R} to show some variation in my strategy and to encourage my opponent to adjust theirs. By doing so, I hope to create more opportunities for potential gains in future rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this particular round, I chose R and my opponent chose B, so I got 0$ while they earned 40$. This suggests that sticking with choice R in this situation may not have been the best decision for me.

As a human player, I would adjust my strategy to account for this outcome and try to minimize losses in future rounds. Given that we are playing a game over 75 rounds, it makes sense to consider a mixed strategy that includes both R and B, but leans more heavily towards choosing B when the opponent chooses R. This approach might help me earn more payoffs in the long run while avoiding situations where I consistently lose money.
